newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity ends mostly up with physicals.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity ends mostly up with physicals.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures settled mostly higher, pushed upwards by higher physicals prices and a forecast for above-normal temperatures in the West, industry sources said.
"The over-the-counter and cash prices did have some effect," one futures broker said.

September California-Oregon Border (COB) settled up 61 cents at $18.86 from trade in a range of $18.45-19.00, while October finished the day up 65 cents at $16.80 after trade in a range of $16.60-17.00 per megawatt hour (MWh).
Remaining COB deferreds finished up between 10 and 55 cents.
September Palo Verde (PV) was down nine cents to $20.95 after trade in a range of $20.30-21.18.
Traders said the September dip may have been the result of weak natural gas prices in the Southwest.
October PV ended 55 cents higher at $16.75, with most remaining PV deferreds ending up 20 cents.
NYMEX said an estimated 223 COB contracts and 58 PV contracts traded.
-- Chris Reese, New York Power Desk 212-859-1627
